repository</strong> of personalized data at the molecular level, molecular-diagnostics companies are uniquely positioned to unlock value. The global market for personalized medicine has grown rapidly since the inception of the Precision Medicine Initiative, announced by Barack Obama during his 2015 State of the Union address. Market research estimated the 2016 global market at
$44 billion in revenues. And these revenues are forecast to more than triple, to $140 billion, by 2026.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="39a6d9b6-e72f-4b2a-8c8a-c8fc7378de28"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="39a6d9b6-e72f-4b2a-8c8a-c8fc7378de28" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Global precision medicine market to reach $141.70 billion by 2026, reports BIS Research,” BIS Research, Cision PR Newswire, December 15, 2017, prnewswire.com.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor-signup mck-o-sm-left-span mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-signup"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-7 DisruptorSignUp_mck-c-disruptor-signup__heading__JR4i0"><div>Stay current on your favorite topics</div></h2></div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--align-left"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/user-registration/register-mvc" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--primary___Ed-lT_990311c mdc-c-button--size-large___jwpUy_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Subscribe</span></a></div></div>
<p>The cost-efficiency of sequencing, a major driver of precision medicine, is improving. Thanks to a number of technological, scientific, and frontline operational advances, the cost of deciphering the entire human genome has dropped by an order of magnitude, from $10,000 in 2011 to about $1,000 today.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1732bb48-d3eb-45e8-b7b3-786fc2ac9e25"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1732bb48-d3eb-45e8-b7b3-786fc2ac9e25" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Thermo Fisher Ion 520 DNA sequencing chip comparison and cost analysis</em>, Research and Markets, February 9, 2018, globenewswire.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Other drivers of precision medicine include more accurate sequencing, a growing number of targeted therapies, and the recognition (especially in oncology and rheumatic illnesses) that diseases are heterogeneous.</p>
<p>Next-generation sequencing (NGS), which is replacing the Sanger method, has become a revolutionary and mature technology widely adopted in academic research and clinical practice. NGS refers to a group of non-Sanger high-throughput sequencing technologies that make it possible to sequence millions of DNA strands in parallel. Despite the advent and rapid growth of whole-genome sequencing (WGS), we expect multigene NGS to remain the largest segment of the market over the next five years. WGS should catch up in the next ten years, a development mainly attributed to reimbursement policies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="295b31ed-08b3-4afd-b656-3125f9eedc4a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="295b31ed-08b3-4afd-b656-3125f9eedc4a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">	Industry survey and expert Interviews.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Diagnostic-test-service providers create value in both tangible and intangible forms. Revenues from pharmaceutical companies, consumers, or payers are clearly tangible, while the potential value of additional insights from collected data is intangible. In this era of bioinformatics, the wealth of data that diagnostic tests generate has become a new option value, like oil-exploration leases, to power the value and strategy of businesses. </p>
<p>Take 23andMe as an example: using genotyping chips, the company offers tests for the genetic blueprint of its customers’ ancestry and health or trait markers. So far, it has gathered data from more than two million customers,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="748d348a-683f-4839-a6e1-37da7ec96bd9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="748d348a-683f-4839-a6e1-37da7ec96bd9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Matthew Herper, “23andMe rides again: FDA clears genetic tests to predict disease risk,” <em>Forbes</em>, April 6, 2017, forbes.com.</span></span></span></a></span> who have the choice of allowing their data to be used for biomedical research. In addition to receiving tangible revenues from selling such genetic tests, 23andMe struck a $60 million deal in 2015 ($10 million up front and $50 million in milestone payments) to give Genentech access to these data.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="be0820ea-00eb-4e8f-986a-66fbeada5cc4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="be0820ea-00eb-4e8f-986a-66fbeada5cc4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">David Shaywitz, “Does 23andMe deal mean medical centers are sitting on data worth millions?” <em>Forbes</em>, January 8, 2015, forbes.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Since then, 23andMe has launched a drug-discovery arm and continued to develop partnerships to give pharmaceutical companies (including Pfizer) access to its data. That illustrates how companies can create value strategically by aggregating genetic information.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/life-sciences/how-we-help-clients">Life Sciences Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header></div></div></div>
<p>F. Hoffmann-La Roche’s recent acquisition of Flatiron Health and Foundation Medicine represents another potential step—this one toward accelerating the progress of precision medicine in oncology. Flatiron Health offers customers its OncologyCloud platform infrastructure, which comprises electronic-medical-record (EMR) work-flow software, longitudinal clinical data, claims billing, and analytics capabilities for two million active cancer patients with all types of tumors.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="48d5bcda-e851-4cb3-b903-60ca87c153a1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="48d5bcda-e851-4cb3-b903-60ca87c153a1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Alex Philippidis, “Roche expands in personalized medicine, oncology with $1.9B purchase of Flatiron Health,” <em>Genetic Engineering & Biotechnology News</em>, February 16, 2018, genengnews.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The Clinico-Genomic Database, codeveloped by Flatiron Health and Foundation Medicine, links the genomic data of 120,000 cancer patients to their longitudinal EMR data.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8a6486d7-6fca-4582-b57b-66c1ea66966f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8a6486d7-6fca-4582-b57b-66c1ea66966f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Alex Philippidis, “Flatiron Health, Foundation Medicine launch clinico-genomic database,” <em>Genetic Engineering & Biotechnology News</em>, November 3, 2016, clinicalomics.com; and Genomic testing FAQ, Foundation Medicine, foundationmedicine.com.</span></span></span></a></span> This provides unprecedented opportunities not only to validate current approaches toward targeted therapy, such as those targeting the anaplastic-lymphoma-kinase (ALK)<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8b615cce-a288-430f-868d-bee289e031f8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8b615cce-a288-430f-868d-bee289e031f8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The anaplastic-lymphoma-kinase (ALK) gene encodes for a protein called ALK receptor tyrosine kinase; genetic alterations in the ALK gene are implicated in cancers including neuroblastoma and lung cancer, “ALK gene,” US National Library of Medicine: Genetics Home Reference, ghr.nlm.nih.gov.</span></span></span></a></span> and epidermal-growth-factor-receptor (EGFR)<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a98f082e-3f79-4929-85a8-7db54602ef18"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a98f082e-3f79-4929-85a8-7db54602ef18" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The epidermal-growth-factor-receptor (EGFR) gene, which encodes for a cell-surface protein, normally helps the cells grow and divide. EGFR inhibitors that block these growth signals can be used to treat non-small cell lung cancers. “Targeted therapy drugs for non-small cell lung cancer,” American Cancer Society, cancer.org.</span></span></span></a></span> mutations, but also to expedite the development of novel targeted therapies. As this example shows, the value of data, when used in a way consistent with data-privacy regulations, comes from its quantity, its quality (for example, data fitness for a specific use case), and its accuracy. </p>
<p>In the United States, the revenues of genetic-testing service providers, which perform tests that healthcare providers use to make diagnoses and guide treatments, come primarily from reimbursements by public and private payers. </p>
<h2>Three major market trends</h2>
<p>Broad industry surveys and expert interviews point to three major trends that will affect the market for genetic testing:</p>
<ol>
    <li>Data integration and analytics to realize <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/spinning-customer-insights-into-business-gold">the value of data</a> have become increasingly important for the healthcare-delivery value chain.</li>
    <li>Payers are facing increasing pressure on costs and looking for new opportunities to control them. </li>
    <li>The US reimbursement landscape, which drives the profitability of most diagnostics players, is gradually evolving.</li>
</ol>
<h3>1. Data integration and analytics</h3>
<p>Thanks to recent technological advances, digital healthcare-data and -analytics capabilities are proliferating. These include (but aren’t limited to) data at the individual level, as well as capabilities that link genetic data with other health indicators, such as medical records and even nonmedical information. Moreover, the general computing trend toward <a href="/featured-insights/artificial-intelligence">artificial intelligence</a> could potentially make these broader but linked data sets even more valuable.</p>
<p>The healthcare data landscape has shifted and expanded as a result of the increased pace of adoption of EMR by office-based physicians, the tracking of patients’ lifestyles, and the large-scale collection of genomic data at different levels. Many stakeholders—for example, eMERGE, IGNITE, and Vanderbilt PREDICT<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6c4d5275-7615-4a4a-8b72-5acb7e6b5b8e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6c4d5275-7615-4a4a-8b72-5acb7e6b5b8e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The eMERGE network, emerge.mc.vanderbilt.edu; Kristin Wiisanen Weitzel et al., “The IGNITE network: A model for genomic medicine implementation and research,” <em>BMC Medical Genomics</em>, January 5, 2016, bmcmedgenomics.biomedcentral .com; and J.M. Pulley et al., “Operational implementation of prospective genotyping for personalized medicine: The design of the Vanderbilt PREDICT project,” <em>Clinical Pharmacology & Therapeutics</em>, July 2012, pp. 87–95.</span></span></span></a></span>—have started to use genomic data linked to EMR for personalized medicine. That is creating an unprecedented opportunity to integrate data sources and generate deeper insights through advanced analytics. </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="How pharma can accelerate business impact from advanced analytics" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/how%20pharma%20can%20accelerate%20business%20impact%20from%20advanced%20analytics/hero-pharma-advanced-analytics.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>How pharma can accelerate business impact from advanced analytics</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/how-pharma-can-accelerate-business-impact-from-advanced-analytics" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Meanwhile, data-privacy laws are becoming stricter. Stakeholders must therefore ensure that their processes collect, retain, and share data in accordance with all applicable privacy laws and regulations. These include the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) in the United States and the <a href="/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/gdpr-compliance-after-may-2018-a-continuing-challenge">General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)</a> in Europe. </p>
<h3>2. Increasing cost pressures</h3>
<p>There are two major reasons for the increasing cost pressures on payers. First, healthcare costs are growing faster than insurance premiums, at a compound annual growth rate of 5 percent<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7494fb3e-7902-465c-9b9e-cce2a8c06f0e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7494fb3e-7902-465c-9b9e-cce2a8c06f0e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“NHE fact sheet,” National Health Expenditures tables, cms.gov.</span></span></span></a></span> and 3 percent,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="421df54b-364d-4837-8245-8899487287d3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="421df54b-364d-4837-8245-8899487287d3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Average annual single premium per enrolled employee for employer-based health insurance,” Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, kff.org.</span></span></span></a></span> respectively, from 2013 to 2016. Second, innovative tests are proliferating: in 2018, more than 30 Current Procedural Terminology (CPT) codes<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="24aca5eb-8637-4e62-aef1-c61bdfbb2515"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="24aca5eb-8637-4e62-aef1-c61bdfbb2515" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Current Procedural Terminology (CPT) medical codes are used to report medical, surgical, and diagnostic procedures and services to physicians, health-insurance companies, and accreditation organizations. They are used along with disease-classification codes as part of the electronic-medical-billing process.</span></span></span></a></span> (the majority focused on oncology genetics testing) were added for reimbursement filings in the United States.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6c57d374-f989-48db-b8cb-6651f5604da8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6c57d374-f989-48db-b8cb-6651f5604da8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Pathology & laboratory 2018 CPT update effective 1/1/2018,” APS Medical Billing, apsmedbill.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Payers therefore use genetic tests in an increasingly sophisticated way and hope that these tests and precision medicine will enable potentially curative or preventative therapies that improve the management of costs.</p>
<p>As cost pressures increase, payers are also gradually shifting from fee-for-service to <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/innovative-pharma-contracts-when-do-value-based-arrangements-work">outcome- and episode-based payment models</a> (Exhibit 1). Outcome-based contracting is a payment-arrangement model between manufacturers and payers: manufacturers commit themselves to give payers rebates based on the performance of therapies in real-world situations. Episode-based payments, also known as bundled payments, base reimbursements to healthcare providers on clinical episodes of care, regardless of the services provided, including a broad range of diagnostic tests, disease-management techniques, and therapies. </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-lg-right-span"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/genetic%20testing%20opportunities%20to%20unlock%20value%20in%20precision%20medicine/svgz-genetic-testing-ex1-expanded.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="In the United States, outcome- and episode-based payments will probably promote interest in (and the reimbursement of) genetic tests." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/genetic%20testing%20opportunities%20to%20unlock%20value%20in%20precision%20medicine/svgz-genetic-testing-ex1-expanded.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Physicians and payers struggle to differentiate among proliferating innovative tests, so clinical studies are needed to demonstrate (for reimbursement purposes) the cost-effectiveness of extensive genetic testing. This approach will promote the adoption and reimbursement of genetic tests that have well-established clinical utility and analytical validation.</p>
<h3>3. The evolving US reimbursement landscape</h3>
<p>The Protecting Access to Medicare Act (PAMA) regulations decreased Medicare (public payer) reimbursement levels by pegging them to payments to private insurers. PAMA, which requires labs to report the amounts private insurers pay for laboratory tests, was signed into law in 2014.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c7a61ed3-5396-4fe1-832c-ed1f53007cff"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c7a61ed3-5396-4fe1-832c-ed1f53007cff" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“PAMA regulations,” US Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services,” cms.gov.</span></span></span></a></span> Medicare used these private-payer rates to update (effective January 1, 2018) the Clinical Laboratory Fee Schedule for laboratory tests. The US Centers for Medicare & Medicaid (CMS) reduced initial payments for clinical lab tests by some 5 to 10 percent. However, the impact may vary dramatically among tests, especially the new molecular-diagnostics ones. </p>
<p>Among therapeutic areas, genetic testing has better recognition for clinical validation and utility in oncology, though many genetic tests for cancers are not approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) or reimbursed. CMS, however, recently announced that it would begin to reimburse FDA-approved NGS tests for patients with advanced cancers, and a few companies (for example, 23andMe, Foundation Medicine, and Oncomine) have made headway obtaining FDA approval for genetic tests in oncology.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bf4cc166-8241-41e3-b6b3-802cd9d5c9b7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bf4cc166-8241-41e3-b6b3-802cd9d5c9b7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Foundation Medicine gains FDA approval, CMS coverage proposal for NGS cancer profiling test,” GenomeWeb, November 30, 2017, genomeweb.com; Aaron Smith, “23andMe gets FDA approval for at-home breast cancer risk test,” CNN tech, March 6, 2018, money.cnn.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Genetic tests are reimbursed at relatively high rates (Exhibit 2): for example, CPT code 81416 for exome sequencing analysis (added early this year) has a national maximum allowable limit of $12,000. Reimbursements for pharmacogenomics, which assesses the way gene variants affect individual responses to drugs, generally cover the sequencing of multiple genes and vary a good deal, from $100 to $2,000. An interesting example—81408, a CPT code at the higher price end, $2,000—covers 24 genes for various disease conditions (Exhibit 3). Quantitative analysis of private-payer reimbursements from 2014 to 2016 indicates that the average level of reimbursement for 81408 has declined, to $1,080 per test, from $1,545. This suggests that higher-priced genetic tests may stabilize at a lower price range.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-lg-right-span"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/genetic%20testing%20opportunities%20to%20unlock%20value%20in%20precision%20medicine/svgz-genetic-testing-ex3-expanded.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Higher-priced genetic tests may stabilize at a lower price range." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/genetic%20testing%20opportunities%20to%20unlock%20value%20in%20precision%20medicine/svgz-genetic-testing-ex3-expanded.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Genetic testing, along with the current blooming of “omics” technologies, will continue to drive the pace of precision medicine. In this golden age of bioinformatics, the reimbursement landscape is evolving. The winners will gain first-mover advantages by seamlessly integrating existing big genetic or molecular data with electronic medical records—in full accordance with data privacy laws—to validate tests clinically and analytically through real-time advanced analytics.</p>
<p>What does it take for a diagnostics player to lead its competitors in the evolving reimbursement paradigm? The future winners will maximize the data-integration opportunities afforded by electronic medical records. This integration suggests to physicians an appropriate diagnostic-test-ordering opportunity with minimal disruption to the clinical-care work flow, and automates the critical preauthorization step that converts reimbursement opportunities to revenues. These diagnostic companies will also develop a substantial knowledge base of publications that demonstrate medical necessity, recognizing that regulatory approval is only the first step in creating evidence for payers. Finally, and even counterintuitively, the most innovative diagnostics companies will have pragmatic product-development road maps that account for the near-term reality that next-generation DNA sequencing with targeted gene-interpretation panels will continue to have patient impact, creating barriers to reimbursement for more nuanced whole-genome approaches. While the future of personalized medicine belongs to big data from genomics and even proteomics, the present revenue realities in genetic diagnostics are still focused on small gene panels.</p>

\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWith a growing repository\u003c/strong\u003e of personalized data at the molecular level, molecular-diagnostics companies are uniquely positioned to unlock value. The global market for personalized medicine has grown rapidly since the inception of the Precision Medicine Initiative, announced by Barack Obama during his 2015 State of the Union address. Market research estimated the 2016 global market at\n$44 billion in revenues. And these revenues are forecast to more than triple, to $140 billion, by 2026.[[Footnote 1]] \u003c/p\u003e\n[[DisruptorSignUp left]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe cost-efficiency of sequencing, a major driver of precision medicine, is improving. Thanks to a number of technological, scientific, and frontline operational advances, the cost of deciphering the entire human genome has dropped by an order of magnitude, from $10,000 in 2011 to about $1,000 today.[[Footnote 2]] Other drivers of precision medicine include more accurate sequencing, a growing number of targeted therapies, and the recognition (especially in oncology and rheumatic illnesses) that diseases are heterogeneous.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNext-generation sequencing (NGS), which is replacing the Sanger method, has become a revolutionary and mature technology widely adopted in academic research and clinical practice. NGS refers to a group of non-Sanger high-throughput sequencing technologies that make it possible to sequence millions of DNA strands in parallel. Despite the advent and rapid growth of whole-genome sequencing (WGS), we expect multigene NGS to remain the largest segment of the market over the next five years. WGS should catch up in the next ten years, a development mainly attributed to reimbursement policies.[[Footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDiagnostic-test-service providers create value in both tangible and intangible forms. Revenues from pharmaceutical companies, consumers, or payers are clearly tangible, while the potential value of additional insights from collected data is intangible. In this era of bioinformatics, the wealth of data that diagnostic tests generate has become a new option value, like oil-exploration leases, to power the value and strategy of businesses. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTake 23andMe as an example: using genotyping chips, the company offers tests for the genetic blueprint of its customers\u0026rsquo; ancestry and health or trait markers. So far, it has gathered data from more than two million customers,[[Footnote 4]] who have the choice of allowing their data to be used for biomedical research. In addition to receiving tangible revenues from selling such genetic tests, 23andMe struck a $60 million deal in 2015 ($10 million up front and $50 million in milestone payments) to give Genentech access to these data.[[Footnote 5]] Since then, 23andMe has launched a drug-discovery arm and continued to develop partnerships to give pharmaceutical companies (including Pfizer) access to its data. That illustrates how companies can create value strategically by aggregating genetic information.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003eF. Hoffmann-La Roche\u0026rsquo;s recent acquisition of Flatiron Health and Foundation Medicine represents another potential step\u0026mdash;this one toward accelerating the progress of precision medicine in oncology. Flatiron Health offers customers its OncologyCloud platform infrastructure, which comprises electronic-medical-record (EMR) work-flow software, longitudinal clinical data, claims billing, and analytics capabilities for two million active cancer patients with all types of tumors.[[Footnote 6]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Clinico-Genomic Database, codeveloped by Flatiron Health and Foundation Medicine, links the genomic data of 120,000 cancer patients to their longitudinal EMR data.[[Footnote 7]] This provides unprecedented opportunities not only to validate current approaches toward targeted therapy, such as those targeting the anaplastic-lymphoma-kinase (ALK)[[Footnote 8]] and epidermal-growth-factor-receptor (EGFR)[[Footnote 9]] mutations, but also to expedite the development of novel targeted therapies. As this example shows, the value of data, when used in a way consistent with data-privacy regulations, comes from its quantity, its quality (for example, data fitness for a specific use case), and its accuracy. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the United States, the revenues of genetic-testing service providers, which perform tests that healthcare providers use to make diagnoses and guide treatments, come primarily from reimbursements by public and private payers. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThree major market trends\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBroad industry surveys and expert interviews point to three major trends that will affect the market for genetic testing:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eData integration and analytics to realize \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/spinning-customer-insights-into-business-gold\"\u003ethe value of data\u003c/a\u003e have become increasingly important for the healthcare-delivery value chain.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ePayers are facing increasing pressure on costs and looking for new opportunities to control them. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe US reimbursement landscape, which drives the profitability of most diagnostics players, is gradually evolving.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e1. Data integration and analytics\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThanks to recent technological advances, digital healthcare-data and -analytics capabilities are proliferating. These include (but aren\u0026rsquo;t limited to) data at the individual level, as well as capabilities that link genetic data with other health indicators, such as medical records and even nonmedical information. Moreover, the general computing trend toward \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/artificial-intelligence\"\u003eartificial intelligence\u003c/a\u003e could potentially make these broader but linked data sets even more valuable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe healthcare data landscape has shifted and expanded as a result of the increased pace of adoption of EMR by office-based physicians, the tracking of patients\u0026rsquo; lifestyles, and the large-scale collection of genomic data at different levels. Many stakeholders\u0026mdash;for example, eMERGE, IGNITE, and Vanderbilt PREDICT[[Footnote 10]]\u0026mdash;have started to use genomic data linked to EMR for personalized medicine. That is creating an unprecedented opportunity to integrate data sources and generate deeper insights through advanced analytics. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis2]]\n\u003cp\u003eMeanwhile, data-privacy laws are becoming stricter. Stakeholders must therefore ensure that their processes collect, retain, and share data in accordance with all applicable privacy laws and regulations. These include the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) in the United States and the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/gdpr-compliance-after-may-2018-a-continuing-challenge\"\u003eGeneral Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)\u003c/a\u003e in Europe. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e2. Increasing cost pressures\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are two major reasons for the increasing cost pressures on payers. First, healthcare costs are growing faster than insurance premiums, at a compound annual growth rate of 5 percent[[Footnote 11]] and 3 percent,[[Footnote 12]] respectively, from 2013 to 2016. Second, innovative tests are proliferating: in 2018, more than 30 Current Procedural Terminology (CPT) codes[[Footnote 13]] (the majority focused on oncology genetics testing) were added for reimbursement filings in the United States.[[Footnote 14]] Payers therefore use genetic tests in an increasingly sophisticated way and hope that these tests and precision medicine will enable potentially curative or preventative therapies that improve the management of costs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs cost pressures increase, payers are also gradually shifting from fee-for-service to \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/innovative-pharma-contracts-when-do-value-based-arrangements-work\"\u003eoutcome- and episode-based payment models\u003c/a\u003e (Exhibit 1). Outcome-based contracting is a payment-arrangement model between manufacturers and payers: manufacturers commit themselves to give payers rebates based on the performance of therapies in real-world situations. Episode-based payments, also known as bundled payments, base reimbursements to healthcare providers on clinical episodes of care, regardless of the services provided, including a broad range of diagnostic tests, disease-management techniques, and therapies. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003ePhysicians and payers struggle to differentiate among proliferating innovative tests, so clinical studies are needed to demonstrate (for reimbursement purposes) the cost-effectiveness of extensive genetic testing. This approach will promote the adoption and reimbursement of genetic tests that have well-established clinical utility and analytical validation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e3. The evolving US reimbursement landscape\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Protecting Access to Medicare Act (PAMA) regulations decreased Medicare (public payer) reimbursement levels by pegging them to payments to private insurers. PAMA, which requires labs to report the amounts private insurers pay for laboratory tests, was signed into law in 2014.[[Footnote 15]] Medicare used these private-payer rates to update (effective January 1, 2018) the Clinical Laboratory Fee Schedule for laboratory tests. The US Centers for Medicare \u0026amp; Medicaid (CMS) reduced initial payments for clinical lab tests by some 5 to 10 percent. However, the impact may vary dramatically among tests, especially the new molecular-diagnostics ones. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmong therapeutic areas, genetic testing has better recognition for clinical validation and utility in oncology, though many genetic tests for cancers are not approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) or reimbursed. CMS, however, recently announced that it would begin to reimburse FDA-approved NGS tests for patients with advanced cancers, and a few companies (for example, 23andMe, Foundation Medicine, and Oncomine) have made headway obtaining FDA approval for genetic tests in oncology.[[Footnote 16]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGenetic tests are reimbursed at relatively high rates (Exhibit 2): for example, CPT code 81416 for exome sequencing analysis (added early this year) has a national maximum allowable limit of $12,000. Reimbursements for pharmacogenomics, which assesses the way gene variants affect individual responses to drugs, generally cover the sequencing of multiple genes and vary a good deal, from $100 to $2,000. An interesting example\u0026mdash;81408, a CPT code at the higher price end, $2,000\u0026mdash;covers 24 genes for various disease conditions (Exhibit 3). Quantitative analysis of private-payer reimbursements from 2014 to 2016 indicates that the average level of reimbursement for 81408 has declined, to $1,080 per test, from $1,545. This suggests that higher-priced genetic tests may stabilize at a lower price range.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eGenetic testing, along with the current blooming of \u0026ldquo;omics\u0026rdquo; technologies, will continue to drive the pace of precision medicine. In this golden age of bioinformatics, the reimbursement landscape is evolving. The winners will gain first-mover advantages by seamlessly integrating existing big genetic or molecular data with electronic medical records\u0026mdash;in full accordance with data privacy laws\u0026mdash;to validate tests clinically and analytically through real-time advanced analytics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat does it take for a diagnostics player to lead its competitors in the evolving reimbursement paradigm? The future winners will maximize the data-integration opportunities afforded by electronic medical records. This integration suggests to physicians an appropriate diagnostic-test-ordering opportunity with minimal disruption to the clinical-care work flow, and automates the critical preauthorization step that converts reimbursement opportunities to revenues. These diagnostic companies will also develop a substantial knowledge base of publications that demonstrate medical necessity, recognizing that regulatory approval is only the first step in creating evidence for payers. Finally, and even counterintuitively, the most innovative diagnostics companies will have pragmatic product-development road maps that account for the near-term reality that next-generation DNA sequencing with targeted gene-interpretation panels will continue to have patient impact, creating barriers to reimbursement for more nuanced whole-genome approaches. While the future of personalized medicine belongs to big data from genomics and even proteomics, the present revenue realities in genetic diagnostics are still focused on small gene panels.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[DisruptorSignUp full-width]]"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2018-10-31T00:30:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Global precision medicine market to reach $141.70 billion by 2026, reports BIS Research,\u0026rdquo;
